Name: bunsen burner,bunsen,burner
Description: It is a standard school grey metal burner with a round base and rotating collar to control the amount of air provided to the flame.
Help: Bunsen burners are great for burning things.

Updates.Value: It is burning with a bright yellow smoky flame.

Conditions.PassResponse: You strike a match out of the box, then turn on the gas supply and light the Bunsen burner. Mr Silver would be furious that you didn't use a lighted split.
Conditions.FailResponse: You don't have anything to light the Bunsen burner with.

State: It is unlit but connected to the gas supply.

Name: fire alarm,alarm
Description: It is a standard fire alarm break-glass, although the glass has already been broken and not repaired, indicating several former pranks.
Help: Triggering the fire alarm will cause a fire drill.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: Alarm bells ring out; all doors open simultaneously, and anxious but well-drilled teachers shepherd pupils enter the hallways. They would escort you too if you weren't physically swept along by the hoards of pupils excited to be missing a lesson and soon arrive outside but unaware of your exact location.

Name: flag pole,pole
Description: It is very tall and made of steel, painted with high-gloss grey paint; the quality of the paint finish is intended to impress.
Help: The flag pole cannot be scaled, but hoisting something up the flag pole would dislodge your history homework.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: It is very tall and smooth, and you couldn't possibly climb it without drawing unwanted attention to yourself, even if it was physically possible.
Although it is made of steel, the flag pole wobbles due to its size when shaken. However, nothing becomes of it other than wasted energy.

State: It is devoid of any flag.

Name: fruit machine,machine,fruity
Description: The standard JDM unit has flashing lights and hold and nudge functionality. The volume has been turned way down, so the endless attract mode does not drive the chippy owner mad.
Help: The fruit machine costs 50 pence to play but yields a healthy jackpot if you're lucky.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You hit and shake the fruit machine, hoping to dispense free money, but the alarm blares, and you hear the owner approaching from the kitchen. Without waiting to see what happens, you scarper until you run out of breath.

Conditions.PassResponse: You insert the slug shaped like a 50-pence piece into the fruit machine nervously, looking over your shoulder twice to ensure no one else is watching. To your delight, the fruit machine zings into life, and you press the start/gamble button a handful of times. The first four spins yield nothing, but on the fifth and final spin, the wheels of the fruit machine align with cherries and a healthy jackpot of coins is deposited. You gather the coins quickly before anyone else can dip into your prize.
Conditions.FailResponse: You can't play the fruit machine for free.
You can't play the fruit machine for free.

Name: laser
Description: It is a coveted laser purchased by the physics department when the Star Wars defence program was announced.
Help: Lasers emit a blinding light, so eye protection is a must.

Updates.Value: The conclusions section of your physics homework has a squiggly laser burn from the accident earlier.

Conditions.PassResponse: You reconnect the wire, tuck it back into the body of the laser and close the panel, knocking the power switch on and firing a red beam of light which reflects off a chrome tap, then off the mirrored sunglasses and finally focus on your physics homework, burning a mark on it.
Conditions.FailResponse: Dr Atom looks up from reading the laser maintenance manual and shouts "Don't touch that! Only members of the physics club are allowed to use it"
Dr Atom looks up from the laser maintenance manual and says "You can play with the laser if you want, but you only get two goes before you are blind"

State: The side panel is open, and a wire is hanging loose.

Name: locker
Description: It is a narrow, wall-mounted metal box providing your private space. It is secured by a key lock rather than an easily guessed combination lock. Losing your locker key will result in turmoil for days.
Help: Lockers often contain very personal items.

Updates.Value: It is unlocked and open, exposing your meagre belongs to the world.

Conditions.PassResponse: You insert the locker key and twist the lock, which emits a horrible metallic squeak; the locker door makes as much noise as its hinges open, exposing your meagre belonging to the world.
Conditions.FailResponse: You are not carrying anything that can unlock your locker.
Your locker is already unlocked and open.

Conditions.PassResponse: You attempt to close the locker door, but it is so old and ill-maintained that the hinges have seized and will no longer close.
Conditions.FailResponse: Your locker is already closed.

State: It is locked shut.

Name: minibus
Description: The minibus is dilapidated and rusty.
State: Its rear doors are locked by a padlock passed through a staple and hasp.

Name: open furnace
Description: The furnace is a small and open gas furnace; it is almost too hot to stand near, but long tongs and thick gauntlets are available to hold items at arm's length when heating them.
Help: A furnace is great for heating or burning items.

Name: padlock
Description: The padlock is a standard brass padlock with a hardened steel shackle.
Help: Lock picking is beyond your capabilities, although fabricating a key is not.

Conditions.FailResponse: You aren't carrying anything that could unlock the padlock.

Conditions.PassResponse: You insert the homemade master key into the padlock and turn it, to your surprise the padlock opens.
Conditions.FailResponse: You aren't carrying anything that could unlock the padlock.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: The padlock is too tiny to be pried open by anything strong enough to break the shackle.

State: The padlock is locked.

Name: piano
Description: The piano is a cheap but well-serviced upright piano.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: Well done! You have damaged the piano.

Updates.Value: It has been damaged by some lout, although it's still playable.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You tickle the ivories and knock out a simple tune without chords.

Name: table saw,saw
Help: Unless you fancy a trip to the hospital, the table saw is best left alone.
Description: The saw is dangerously unguarded and can be turned on with a simple switch to make it even less safe.

Name: vice
Description: The vice is an intense bench-mounted vice capable of holding most small objects firmly so they can be worked on vigorously,
Help: Vices are great for holding small pieces of metal while they are fabricated.

Name: view
Description: The view from the school roof is awe-inspiring; it shows the history of the town's conurbational growth via the diverse collection of domiciles home to the town's denizens. It is the best part of the school.
Help: The view is so inspirational it should be captured somehow.

Updates.Value: Today's page of your art homework folder shows a beautiful vista of the town.

Conditions.PassResponse: you sketch on your art homework using your trusted pencil and quickly create a facsimile of the beautiful vista - to the best of your abilities.
Conditions.FailResponse: You are not carrying anything to draw with.
You are not carrying anything to draw on.

Name: administration office
Description: The office is the most efficient room in the entire school. Filing cabinets line all the walls; above them, shelves are stacked end-to-end with ring-bound folders.
Help: Every single record of every single pupil is stored in this room.

Name: art studio
Description: The studio is a large room that is light and airy to facilitate the creative art process. Exhibits from former pupils adorn the wall, leaving little space for new submissions unless they are deemed better than those already existing.

Name: assembly hall
Description: The hall is the hub of school assembly for internal curriculum activities and the wider community. The hall hosts everything from morning assembly, music concerts, and dramatic performances for pupils to ballet voting and bingo sessions for the locals.

Name: athletics field
Description: The field is a vast expanse of grass with no discernable marking of any kind. It is used for javelin and discus throwing during summer and long-distance running during autumn, winter, and spring.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You trek across the athletics field, which takes forever.
You trek across the athletics field, which takes forever.
You trek across the athletics field, which takes forever.

Name: audio lab
Description: The room is like a high-tech classroom in the 1970s. Instead of desks, it is filled with partitioned booths, each containing a pair of uncomfortable pre-war-looking headphones and an open reel tape deck made from bakelite.

Name: back gate
Description: The gate is a pedestrian-only entrance to the school; it is a large rusty metal gate flanked by matching metal railing to supposedly keep people out but more likely pupils in.

Name: back stage
Description: Backstage is as old and rough as the rest of the stage, although it clearly indicates the academic and social divide; anyone who needs more intellectual understanding to be a teacher's pet is doomed to only ever become a behind-the-scenes stage hand in any school productions.

Name: back street
Description: The street is a narrow but busy road frequented by many pupils who attend school, those who live to the west and others who visit the local shops during lunch break. There are no concessions for pupil safety here, no crossing or traffic calming.

Name: behind the bike sheds
Description: This is notoriously the most illicit area in the school; the name alone is synonymous with unauthorised activities, from heavy petting to smoking. As if further proof is needed, the ground is littered with cigarette butts.
Help: Cigarettes can be used as currency in school.

Name: bike sheds
Description: The sheds are filled with various bicycles, from racers to BMXs and shoppers to choppers. They are all diligently locked up as a bike is usually a school pupil's most expensive item.
Help: To get home, you will need your bike.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: Although there isn't much room, you squeeze between the end of the bike-covered racks and the overgrown shrubbery.

Conditions.FailResponse: Mr Broom appears immediately in your path. "Hoy! No bikes in school! I shouldn't have to keep telling you kids" he informs you before returning to his regular work.

Name: bins
Description: The area contains a collection of large galvanized steel cylindrical bins on wheels. Most bins are covered, but one has no lid; its stench is disgusting, so it's advisable to leave here quickly.
Help: Where there's muck, there's brass.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You head west and turn the corner to the south.
You take a run-up at the bin and get enough of a grip on the rim and traction from your shoes to clear the top.

Name: binside
Description: Inside the bin, it smells even worse than outside, but be thankful that you have entered the right way up, unlike many previous unwilling visitors! You are standing on many feet deep rubbish, but at least this will allow you to exist easily.
Help: Binside is a portmanteau of bin and inside.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You climb out of the bin, and your nose thanks you.

State: The smell is offensive.

Name: biology lab
Description: The lab is filled with old-fashioned fixed benches in ranks lined with high bar-like stools. This allows gas and water supplies to the benches to facilitate experiments. It still retains old-fashioned blackboards at the front of the lab. This lab is distinct for its view over the school's science courtyard, like a "Blue Peter" garden but off-limits to pupils.

Name: blue bridge
Description: The bridge is a steel pedestrian bridge spanning the main road, named for its colour. It is safe from traffic here.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You cross the remainder of the bridge and climb down the dog-leg steps.
You cross the remainder of the bridge and climb down the dog-leg steps.

Name: car park
Description: The car park is filled with various cars ranging from teachers' classics, the headmaster's modern luxury saloon, and the starter cars of the eldest and richest sixth formers.

Conditions.FailResponse: all the minibus doors are locked.

Name: caretaker's office
Description: The office is in name only and an extension of the store room. Items are scattered across the room, piled high and stacked deep. Although there is a desk, it is covered by ring binders of inventories, maintenance instructions, and schedules, leaving no space to work.

Name: chemistry lab
Description: The lab is filled with old-fashioned fixed benches in ranks lined with high bar-like stools. This allows gas and water supplies to the benches to facilitate experiments. It still retains old-fashioned blackboards at the front of the lab. This lab is distinct for its view over the school's science courtyard, like a "Blue Peter" garden but off-limits to pupils.

Name: chinese takeaway
Description: The takeaway is affectionately known as the 'chippy'. The takeaway restaurant is sparse but adorned with Chinese decor.

Name: computer room
Description: The room is sparse and has only a single computer, a Commodore PET, which is mainly off-limits to pupils. Connecting the PET to another computer worldwide via a phone line using a modem with an acoustic coupler is possible. Unfortunately, this is also off-limits.

Name: cooking room
Description: The room is lined with worktops, sinks and half as many ovens. There is an enormous industrial-sized fridge in the corner for storing spoilable ingredients. For safety reasons, you cannot use any equipment without express permission.
Help: Ovens make things hot, and fridges make things cold.

Name: corridor of gloom
Description: The corridor has a horrific sense of dread that overwhelms you as very little natural light exists. It's the central hub of paths behind the entrance hall. Still, its forebodingness sums up the remainder of the school accurately.
Help: Go towards the light, although not metaphorically.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You ascend the dog-leg stairs and end up directly above where you started.

Name: covered path
Description: The path is the main thoroughfare through the school, joining the front of the building to the back while avoiding all classrooms and offices in between. Although outdoors, the path is covered with a clear plastic canopy, which allows dry passage during the rain.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You head north and turn the corner to the east.

Name: cricket pitch
Description: The pitch is rarely used and only visited in summer. However, it is well-maintained thanks partly to an all-weather surface between the stumps.

Name: drama cupboard
Description: The cupboard contains small props for the school plays and various costumes. If you've ever wanted to be a Roman centurion or a ghost, this is the place to be.
Help: Drama costumes allow actors to become other people, albeit as part of a subterfuge.

Name: drama room
Description: The room has chairs and benches without desks arranged in a circle. There are also a few oversized props, such as trees and walls. It smells the same as backstage here.

Conditions.PassResponse: You sneak into the drama cupboard dramatically.
Conditions.FailResponse: The drama cupboard is locked.

Name: east canteen
Description: The canteen does not have enough seating for the amassed pupils, so a shift pattern is employed to ensure all pupils enjoy the experience daily.
Help: The east canteen is oozing with vanity.
State: It is packed with popular pupils, and everyone is doing their best to out-dress each other, like strutting peacocks to become the alpha male or female.

Name: east stairwell first floor
Description: The stairwell is well-lit by floor-to-ceiling windows. The first floor is where the pomp ends and is the floor of learning.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You ascend the down-leg stairs and end up directly above where you started.
You descend the down-leg stairs and end up directly below where you started.

Name: east stairwell second floor
Description: The stairwell is well-lit by floor-to-ceiling windows. The second floor represents even more intense levels of academia.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You ascend the down-leg stairs and end up directly above where you started.
You descend the down-leg stairs and end up directly below where you started.

Name: east toilets
Description: The toilets are very unpleasant; most stalls are broken without locks or even doors, and the remaining stalls are soiled beyond what is believable. There is a row of thankfully clean hand basins, half of which have working taps.
Help: There is a plentiful supply of water in the toilets.

Name: english language
Description: The room has walls covered with information about the correct use of punctuation, case, tense, nouns, verbs,  similies, metaphors and onomatopoeias, yet strangely, nothing of swear words; something that exists in equal measures in the real world.
Help: Swearing will get you an immediate detention in any part of the school. Still, if used grammatically correctly here, you might get away with it.

Conditions.PassResponse: You pluck up all your courage, step onto the open window sill and leap forward. You grab your nose as you plummet earthward and splash into the swimming pool unhurt.
Conditions.FailResponse: You look out the open window at the swimming pool below, with its murky green water and think better of it.

Name: english literature
Description: The room walls are covered with posters of Shakespeare, Keats, Dickens, Orwell, Eliot, Chaucer, Tolkien and Wordsworth. Here, you are expected to forget everything you learned about the modern English language next door and appreciate an unrecognisable language from centuries ago.
Help: To be, or not to be?

Name: entrance hall
Description: The hall exhibits all the pomp and circumstance required to lull parents into a false belief that the school is being run professionally. The cracks are showing and are not as well maintained as the public façade outside. Celebrations of current local festivals adorn the walls with endless contributions from pupils.
Help: You feel very conspicuous, so don't do anything silly.

Conditions.FailResponse: It would be wise to leave school with your trusty pencil; not only will you be unable to do any homework, but you will unlikely be readmitted to school.

Name: first aid room
Description: The room is small but well-stocked with medical supplies. It smells of antiseptic, and there is a single bed in the corner; this is the only place in the entire school where you are authorised to lie down.
Help: If you need to vomit, this is the best place to do it.

Name: flat roof
Description: The roof is an expansive area of flat grey roofing felt covering the whole school footage, save some plant and chimney stacks. A small parapet around the edge is only high enough to provide a trip hazard.
Help: The roof would make an excellent go-kart track.

Name: football pitch
Description: The pitch is full-sized, with a five-a-side pitch perpendicular to it at the north end. This is where most imaginationless physical exercise occurs, usually as shirts vs. skins in all weather.
Help: Association football is also know as soccer.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You trek across the football pitch, which takes forever.
You trek across the football pitch, which takes forever.
You trek across the football pitch, which takes forever.
You trek across the football pitch, which takes forever.

State: It is churned from players wearing studded football boots in wet weather.

Name: french room
Description: Les murs sont recouverts d'affiches représentant des stéréotypes de la culture française, des phrases interminables et des exemples de situations de la langue française. Rien n'est en anglais ici.
Help: Je ne comprends pas.

Name: front path
Description: The path is well attended, and the surrounding lawns are immaculate; the entire school maintenance budget may have been spent here merely to impress passers-by and anyone who won't ever venture inside.
Help: Mr Head is keen that all pupils are permanently equipped for learning, which starts with a humble pencil. You remember last having your pencil in a nearby shop.

Conditions.PassResponse: Mr Head leaps out to confront you, but seeing your trusty pencil return to his regular beat, this is not the last time you will need your trusty pencil, so don't lose it.
Conditions.FailResponse: Mr Head leaps in front of you, blocks your progress and scorns "You look ill-equipped for a day of learning in my exemplary academic institution." while failing to tell you the exact problem before disappearing.

Name: front street
Description: The street runs north/south, with the school to the west. It is the greyest, gloomiest place in the morning; after 15:30, it's a brightly lit golden pathway to freedom and happiness.
Help: You will need all the help you can get because last night's homework assignments were English, French, maths, physics, biology, chemistry, geography, history, woodwork, metalwork, P.E., GED, art, home economics and drama. Good job, there was less than usual homework yesterday!

Conditions.PassResponse: You have completed your goal!
Conditions.FailResponse: Home is over 2 miles away; riding your iron steed is the only way to reach home.

Name: ged hut
Description: The GED (Geometric Engineering and Design) hut is a wooden classroom. It is bitterly cold in winter, and the bare wooden floor allows the draught to whistle between the floorboards. Each desk has an adjustable tilting drawing surface with an attached horizontal rule and other multiple geometric drawing attachments.
Help: Pencils softer than 2h are banned in this classroom.

Name: geography room
Description: The room walls are covered with maps: world maps, terrain maps, geo-political maps, topological maps and geographical features such as oxbow lakes and volcanoes.
Help: Knowledge of oxbow lakes and volcanos won't help you as an adult. Still, map reading will yield dividends immediately, such as finding your way around the school.

Name: german room
Description: Die Wände sind mit Plakaten bedeckt, die die stereotype deutsche Kultur, endlose Phrasen und situative Beispiele der deutschen Sprache darstellen. Hier ist nichts auf Englisch.
Help: Ich verstehe nicht.

Name: gloomy path
Description: The path leads from the primary school building to the outbuildings and temporary wooden classrooms, affectionately known as huts. This path leads to your homeroom and needs to be covered, meaning that a rainy start to the school day is as miserable as it gets.

Name: grassy area
Description: The area between the huts borders your homeroom and is a gathering area before class registration each morning. Being outdoors and subject to the elements means waiting for class to open, which often means getting wet.

Conditions.PassResponse: Mr Square greets you with a smile, a rarity among teachers.
Conditions.FailResponse: Mr Square blocks your path. "All the compasses have been stolen, probably for homemade tattooing; you'll need to provide your own this week." he assumes.
Mr Square blocks your path. "Come on! You know the rules. Anything less than H2 will carbon-stain the equipment and cause smudges." he asserts.

Name: grassy common
Description: The common is a small grassy area separating traffic to the south and houses to the north, accompanied by a row of shops. It is frequented primarily by dog walkers.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You cross the common, followed by the street and are drawn into the Chinese takeaway.

Name: gym
Description: The gym is a large hall with a shiny parquet floor with different court markings. Badminton, tennis, netball, five-a-side football and basketball courts can be made out, but the others are a mystery.

Name: gym changing room
Description: The changing room is as essential as any room: bare walls and brown tiled floor. Even the wooden slat benches are utilitarian with grey metal hanging pegs. There are no soft furnishings for any odour to cling to.
Help: Your privates are not private here.

Name: hall corridor
Description: The corridor runs the length of the assembly hall to the west of the hall and is commonly used to queue for the gym or assembly hall. Sometimes, pupils will be ejected from assemblies and made to stand in the hall corridor. However, this is less of a punishment than attending assemblies.

Name: headmaster's office
Description: The headmaster's office is the most intimidating room in the entire school. Despite the school headmaster effectively being the CEO of the school, he still likes to medal in individual pupil disciplinaries. The walls are faded cream, and all the woodwork is ancient; the only thing that looks modern is the numerous certificates and citation frames hung on the walls.

Name: hidden
Description: This is an unreachable location used to hide items from the player.

Name: history room
Description: The room walls are adorned with stock pictures of British kings and queens; however, no lessons ever focus on this part of history. Other posters highlight the current curriculum of crop rotation in the 14th century, so it is pointless to anyone who isn't going to become a farmer.
Help: Those who do not learn history are doomed to repeat it.

Name: home room
Description: The homeroom is where classes gather for registration before banding lessons, twice daily, in the morning and after lunch. For some pupils, this is as long as they stay in school daily. The room is a laboratory but is rarely used for lessons.

Name: home store room
Description: The store room separates the home room and the weird room labs, with access doors leading to each. There is a large selection of supplies for a variety of lessons.

Name: inside the minibus
Description: The minibus is sparse, with scant regard for the safety of its occupants. Two wooden slat bench seats run the length of the van on either side with no restraints, meaning that occupants travel sideways and face each other while being thrown about. With the right people on board, this is the most fun you could ever have at school.
Help: Throwing oranges and other round fruit out the window won't help you here, but it is very amusing.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You exit the low-roofed minibus and unfold yourself into a standing position once again.

Name: kitchen
Description: The kitchen is significant on an industrial scale; the floor is covered in practical tiles, and oversized cooking utensils hang around the room above large sinks and cookers - even the supplies are oversized to cater for all the pupils and staff. It has a perma-small of cooked food.
Help: You aren't allowed in the kitchen, it's too dangerous for pupils, although you will be expected to use a kitchen for the rest of your life, so it can't be that bad.

Name: library
Description: The library is the quietest place in the school and is the only room that can be visited at any time of day, during lessons, break time or lunch. Wooden bookshelves line the walls with small piers protruding to form nooks, which allow pupils to hide from teachers easily. A card-based index system exists to locate books, but generally, it's easier to browse alphabetically for them.
Help: Shhh!

Name: library corridor
Description: The corridor is the hub of directions, often lined with pupils queuing up to enter the library or art studio. However, there is very little mischief due to its proximity to the staff room.

Conditions.PassResponse: Mr Head fleetingly appears but, due to the brilliance of your disguise, assumes you are a staff member and goes about his business.
Conditions.FailResponse: From nowhere, Mr. Head appears and blocks your path, "You know pupils aren't allowed in the staff room", he asserts, seemingly vanishing again.
From nowhere, Mr. Head appears and blocks your path, "You know pupils aren't allowed in the staff room", he asserts, seemingly vanishing again.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You ascend the down-leg stairs and end up directly above where you started.

Name: lockers
Description: Generic grey steel lockers line every square foot of the wall in this corridor, leading to its name. The only free wall space is the entrances, including the west stairwell's foot.
Help: Lockers provide storage for items and keep them secret from others.

Name: main road
Description: The main road through the town runs east/west with two lanes of traffic in each direction, intersecting the school street at an ample traffic light-controlled junction. Due to the traffic volume, the only way across is via a pedestrian bridge.

Actions.UnconditionalResponse: You climb the dog-leg steps of the blue bridge and walk across to the middle of the bridge's span.

Name: main store room
Description: The storeroom has a musty smell and is lined by rows of freestanding shelving units. Unsurprisingly, it is full of school antiquities, most of which look like they last used decades ago and are unfamiliar to you.

Name: maths room
Description: The room has no posters on the walls. Maths-related posters would look too childish here. Instead, the walls are bare and uninviting.

Name: metal workshop
Description: The workshop is full of lathes, pillar drills, and surrounding benches with rows of vices. In the corner is a furnace for heating metal to hazardous temperatures, complete with a bucket for quenching and case hardening.
Help: The metal workshop is a great place for working metals of all types.

Name: music room
Description: The room is unique because it feels less like an academic classroom than any other one. It is twice the size of other classrooms and filled with more instruments than chairs and desks.
Help: The music room is by far the loudest room in the school and the only room where you won't be punished for making noise.

Name: news agent
Description: The shop is a misnomer; although it sells newspapers, it sells just about everything from magazines, snacks, groceries and school supplies. No more than four pupils are allowed in at any time to reduce the chances of thievery.
Help: Being located opposite a school it sells plenty of items that would be helpful during a normal schoolday.

Name: north copse
Description: The copse is a small haven from the rest of the school. The trees here provide a dense canopy of leaves, which prevents any sun from penetrating and offers seclusion when the deciduous trees have leaves.

Name: north driveway
Description: The driveway connects the school property to the public road and allows small vehicle access. The north driveway entrance is used mainly by pupils who cycle to school, those who live the furthest away and don't have the luxury of generous parents to provide endless taxi services.
Help: The driveway is the only place to take bicycles into and out of the school property. But even with your bike, you are unlikely to escape with submitting all your homework assignments from last night: English, French, maths, physics, biology, chemistry, geography, history, woodwork, metalwork, P.E., GED, art, home economics and drama.

Conditions.PassResponse: you scoot your bike through the north gate and for once your are not confronted by anyone in authority.
Conditions.FailResponse: Mr Broom appears from nowhere and prevents you from going any further; he shouts "Vehicular access only! Don't you know pedestrians and vehicles don't mix?" before going about his other business.

Miss Battle prevents you from leaving, insisting that you still need to hand in your history homework, although her gaze never strays from the direction of the front path.
Miss French vous empêche de partir, insistant sur le fait que vous devez encore terminer vos devoirs de français.
Mr Ball prevents you from leaving, insisting that you still need to hand in your P.E. homework while jogging on the spot.
Dr Atom prevents you from leaving, insisting you still need to hand in your physics homework.

Mr Foot leaps out in front of you like an energetic frog and prevents you from leaving school, "you don't seem to have submitted your biology homework." he asserts firmly before hopping off as quickly as he appeared.
Mr Square prevents you from leaving, insisting that you still need to hand in your homework - he seems aggrieved at having to ask you. He would prefer to draw isometric objects elsewhere.
Mr Rhumb prevents you from leaving, insisting that you still need to hand in your geography homework, although it pains him to do so.
Mr Silver prevents you from leaving, insisting that you still must hand in your chemistry homework.

Miss Sketch timidly chases after you and politely informs you that you haven't submitted your art homework yet; she is so lovely it would be a crime not to hand in your art homework before going home.
Miss Sharp prevents you from leaving, stating almost song like that you must still hand in your music homework.
Mr Saw prevents you from leaving, insisting you still need to submit your woodwork homework.
Mrs Bakewell prevents you from leaving, hungrily insisting that you still must hand in your home economics homework.
Mr Bodmas leaps out from nowhere and prevents you from leaving school; "I don't seem to have your maths homework." he asserts firmly before disappearing as quickly as he appeared.
Miss McQueen prevents you from leaving, stating that you must still hand in your homework as dramatically as she can.
Mr Booker prevents you from leaving, delivers a monologue and insists that you hand in your English homework.
Mr Steel prevents you from leaving, stating that he has not received your metalwork homework.

Name: north street
Description: The street has an eclectic collection of detached and semi-detached houses lining each side; their value would increase significantly if fewer school kids were traipsing past twice daily.

Conditions.FailResponse: Mr Broom appears and prevents you from going any further; he says "Vehicular access only! Don't you know pedestrians and vehicles don't mix?" before going about his business.

Name: physics lab
Description: The lab is filled with old-fashioned fixed benches in ranks lined with high bar-like stools. This allows gas and water supplies to the benches to facilitate experiments.
